protocol.title: Isolation, Culture, and Maintenance of Patient-Derived Tumor Biopsy
protocol.title_html: Isolation, Culture, and Maintenance of Patient-Derived Tumor Biopsy

source.description:
Store tissue samples in cold transport media (
). Keep samples on ice at all time and process within
Transfer the tumor biopsy sample (1-2 cm3) and transport media into a petri dish and remove remnant non-tumor tissue with sterile tweezers.

source.body: The size of the tissue sample will affect the cells yield and the end of the protocol. Make sure to get enough tissue sample (~ 1-2cm3)

source.description: Transfer the tumor tissue to a new petri dish and cut the sample into small pieces with a sterile razor blade (<2 mm2).

Add
of cold sterile PBS to the dish and transfer the tumor fragments and PBS to a 15 ml centrifuge tube, pipetting up and down for three times.

Allow the tissue fragments to settle by gravity for
, remove and discard the supernatant

Resuspend the tissue fragments in
HBSS buffer plus Collagenase and transfer to a fresh 15 ml tube.

Place the tube in
and incubate the enzymatic digestion at
for
.

source.body: The time of cell digestion will affect the cells yield and the end of the protocol. Make sure to incubate for enough time

source.description:
Quench the enzymatic digestion by adding
of cold, sterile FBS to the reaction and proceed immediately to plating for organoid culture.

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description: Warm up a 24-well flat bottom plate in the incubator and cool the 10% FBS solution on ice.

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description: Strain the quenched enzyme solution through a 70 um cell strainer into a 15 ml tube using a reducing adaptors assembly. Use one cell strainer, reducing adaptor and tube per sample.

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description:
Wash the cells twice in
of 10% FBS by pipet up and down at least 10 times then centrifuging the sample for 3 minutes at 2000g to pellet the cells.

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description:
Resuspend the cell pellet in 1 ml basal media and determine the cellular yield using a hemocytometer.
For instructions on using hemocytometer:

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description:
Transfer the desired cell sample to a fresh tube and
to pellet the cells. Discard the supernatant. Do not remove the pellet.

source.body: The following steps are for plating 4 x culture domes. If fewer or additional culture domes are required based on the counts in step 5, adjust the volume of Matrigel and PBS.

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description:
Thoroughly resuspend the cells in
of cold PBS by pipetting up and down 10 times. Avoid introducing bubbles.

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description:
Add
of Matrigel to the cell solution and mix by pipetting up and down 10 times. Avoid introducing bubbles.

source.body: Keep the Matrigel all the time, at room temperature will start to polymerization

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description:
Gently plate
domes of the Matrigel-cell suspension in the center of the 4 central wells in the pre-warm 24 well flat bottom plate.

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description:
Carefully transfer the plate to
incubator and incubate for at least
to allow domes to solidify (polymerize).

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description:
Gently add
of basal media + small molecules to each well by pipetting the media gently down the wall of the well.

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description: Optional: Add sterile PBS to the unused wells of the 24 well plate to limit evaporation.

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description: Place the lid on the culture plate and return it to the tissue culture incubator.

source.title: Plating Cancer Cells for 3D Organoid Culture

source.description:
Perform a full media change every
to expand organoids. Observe cancer organoids daily and replace the media every 2 days after cancer cell isolation. Proceed to the next phases (drug screening, passage organoids and cryopreservation) after 4 or 5 days.
Carefully remove media from each well.

source.body: Passage must be performed between 7 or 10 days depending on organoid size and density, passaging helps to avoid the organoid overgrowth and keeps the culture healthy and expanding.

source.description:
Gently add
cold PBS to each well by pipetting the PBS gently down the wall of the well.
Carefully remove and discard PBS from each well.

Add
of accumax on the top of the dome in each well and perform mechanical detach from the bottom (gently scrape).

Carefully transfer the plate to 37°C incubator. Incubate at
for
Collect and transfer the accumax-cell suspension to a 15 ml tube.

Add
of FBS to get 10% FBS and pipette up and down the accumax-cell suspension at least 10 times.

Centrifuge the sample for
to pellet the cells. Do not remove the pellet.

Remove the 24 well flat bottom plate from the
incubator.

Add
of PBS to the sample tube. Pipette up and down 10 times to thoroughly resuspend the pellet. Avoid introducing bubbles.

Add
of Matrigel to the sample tube. Pipette up and down 10 times to thoroughly resuspend the pellet. Avoid introducing bubbles.

Gently add
of Matrigel-cell suspension in 4 central wells of a pre-warm 24 well plate. This protocol uses a 1:2 split ratio on passage organoid between 7 to 10 days after plating, or when the density reaches 150 organoids per well.

Carefully transfer the plate to 37°C incubator. Incubate at
for at least
to allow domes to solidify (polymerization).

Gently add
of conditioned media to each well by pipetting the media gently down the wall of the well.

Place the lid on the culture plate and incubate at
and 5% CO2.
Every 2 days perform a full media change.
Carefully remove media from each well and add 1 ml of recovery cell culture freezing medium per well.
Scrape the Matrigel off the bottom of the wells with a 1,000 ul pipette and transfer the cancer organoids into a one cryovial. Label with date and tissue source or any other specifications.

Place each tube in a freezing container and incubate the tubes at
for at least 1 day.
Transfer the frozen cryovials to a liquid nitrogen storage tank. Cancer organoids can be kept in liquid nitrogen storage for at least 3 years.

Remove the cryovials from storage and thaw them quickly in a
water bath.
Collect the organoids with a 1,000 µl pipette into a 15-ml centrifuge tube.

Add
of basal media and spin the organoids down at
Remove and discard the supernatant and suspend the organoids with Matrigel.

The appropriate volume of Matrigel depends on the number of the cancer organoids. In most cases splitting one vial (1000 µl) of preserved organoids to 4-6 wells of a 24 well flat bottom plate is enough.

Gently add
of Matrigel-cell suspension in 4 central wells of a pre-warm 24 well plate.

Carefully transfer the plate to 37°C incubator. Incubate at
for at least
to allow domes to solidify (polymerization).

Gently add
of conditioned media to each well by pipetting the media gently down the wall of the well.
Place the lid on the culture plate and incubate at 37°C and 5% CO2.
Every 2 days perform a full media change.

materials.name: Externally and Internally Threaded Cryogenic Storage Vials
Corning® Matrigel® Growth Factor Reduced (GFR) Basement Membrane Matrix

description:
This protocol is split into 3 sections: collecting tumor cells, passaging, and cryopreserving organoids.
Phase 1:
Aim:Collect viable cells from biopsy samples
Tumor organoid: Colorectal Cancer
Source: Human primary tissue
Phase 2:
Aim: Passage and expand organoid samples
Phase 3:
Aim: Organoid cryopreservation
Tumor organoid: Colorectal Cancer
Source: Human primary tissue
